newsitem.title: USA: Computer Associates appeal denied by court.
newsitem.headline: Computer Associates appeal denied by court.

text.p: A New York Supreme Court judge declined to hear an appeal by Computer Associates International Inc regarding a royalty dispute and called for the company to pay an arbitration award of about $13.8 million, plaintiffs in the case said on Monday.

The plaintiffs -- developers of a software applications development tool called DataVantage -- said the company was also ordered to turn over to them extensive records relating to the product. The ruling upholds an earlier one by Judge Harold Tompkins.
Computer Associates said it planned to comply with the court's order even though it disagreed with decision. The company plans no further appeal.

Computer Associates said the case stemmed from a dispute over royalties between DataVantage developers and On-Line Software International Inc. It was inherited when Computer Associates acquired On-Line in 1991.

DataVantage simplifies testing and system assurance on mainframe computers. The product is seen as having applications in fixing computer problems related to recognizing dates beginning the year 2000.
The software developers are represented by the law firm of Phillips, Nizer, Benjamin, Krim & Ballon LLP.
